articles.headline: Exoneration Using DNA Brings Change in Legal System
articles.snippet: All but eight states now give inmates access to DNA evidence that might not have been available at the time of their convictions.
articles.abstract: All but eight states now give inmates access to DNA evidence that might not have been available at the time of their convictions.
articles.lead_paragraph: State lawmakers across the country are adopting broad changes to criminal justice procedures as a response to the exoneration of more than 200 convicts through the use of DNA evidence.

articles.headline: Loyal Network Backs Obama After His Help
articles.snippet: Barack Obama’s courtship of a group of black entrepreneurs shows the link between money and politics.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama’s courtship of a group of black entrepreneurs shows the link between money and politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2000, after losing a Congressional race, Barack Obama was looking to revive his political fortunes. And he soon found a springboard — a group of black entrepreneurs also trying to break out.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Raymond Hernandez

articles.headline: More Hollywood Studios Say ‘No Smoking’
articles.snippet: Hollywood’s big movie studios are divided on whether to show cigarette smoking in films that are likely to be seen by young audiences.
articles.abstract: Hollywood’s big movie studios are divided on whether to show cigarette smoking in films that are likely to be seen by young audiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 — In the movie musical “Dreamgirls” last year, James “Thunder” Early, Eddie Murphy’s soul-singing, chain-smoking character, was so infuriated by a fumbled food order that he mashed his cigarette into a chicken sandwich that was supposed to have no mayonnaise.

articles.headline: At Starbucks, Songs of Instant Gratification
articles.snippet: New technology that allows coffee patrons to download the music playing in Starbucks stores to their iPhones is just the beginning of a wave of options for impulse purchases.
articles.abstract: New technology that allows coffee patrons to download the music playing in Starbucks stores to their iPhones is just the beginning of a wave of options for impulse purchases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like that song you hear playing at Starbucks, but just cannot wait until you get to a computer to download the song?

articles.headline: Fatal Airplane Crashes Drop 65%
articles.snippet: The improvements come in part from efforts by airlines to identify and fix common precursors to accidents.
articles.abstract: The improvements come in part from efforts by airlines to identify and fix common precursors to accidents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 — After two infamous crashes in 1996 that together killed 375 people, a White House commission told the airline industry and its regulators to reduce the domestic rate of fatal accidents 80 percent over 10 years. That clock ended Sunday.

articles.headline: Why Big Newspapers Applaud Some Declines in Circulation
articles.snippet: Many big newspapers are cutting promotions and choosing smaller circulation numbers, hoping to lure advertisers with a more focused and engaged readership.
articles.abstract: Many big newspapers are cutting promotions and choosing smaller circulation numbers, hoping to lure advertisers with a more focused and engaged readership.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the newspaper industry bemoans falling circulation, major papers around the country have a surprising attitude toward a lot of potential readers: Don’t bother.

articles.headline: Darfur Rebels Kill 10 in Peace Force
articles.snippet: Hundreds of Darfurian rebels overran an African Union peacekeeping base in central Darfur, African Union officials said.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of Darfurian rebels overran an African Union peacekeeping base in central Darfur, African Union officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 30 — Hundreds of Darfurian rebels overran an African Union peacekeeping base in the central Darfur region of Sudan in a surprise raid over the weekend, killing at least 10 soldiers, possibly kidnapping dozens more and seizing supplies that included heavy weapons, African Union officials said Sunday.

articles.headline: For the Rich, Magazines Fat on Ads
articles.snippet: While much of the magazine industry scrambles to fight off the Web and irrelevancy, there is a bull market in titles that target the wealthy.
articles.abstract: While much of the magazine industry scrambles to fight off the Web and irrelevancy, there is a bull market in titles that target the wealthy.
articles.lead_paragraph: The rich will always be a good bet in publishing. First, they have the money, at least most of it. Second, they have the time, which is the by far the biggest luxury of our age.

articles.headline: The Everyman Who Exposed Tainted Toothpaste
articles.snippet: Eduardo Arias’s glance at an ingredient list led to a worldwide hunt for tainted toothpaste.
articles.abstract: Eduardo Arias’s glance at an ingredient list led to a worldwide hunt for tainted toothpaste.
articles.lead_paragraph: PANAMA — Eduardo Arias hardly fits the profile of someone capable of humbling one of the world’s most formidable economic powers.
